abstract.para: Chlorophyll A, Active, Pheopigments and Total for the lakes and streams during the summer of 1991.

intellectualRights.para: Acceptance and utilization of LTER data requires that:

listitem.para: The Principal Investigator be sent a notice stating reasons for acquiring any data and a description of the publication intentions.
The Principal Investigator of the data set be sent a copy of the report or manuscript prior to submission and be adequately cited in any resultant publications
A copy of any resultant publications should be sent to:Principal Investigator Ecosystems Center Marine Biological Laboratory Woods Hole, MA 02543

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Toolik, N1, N2, E1, S6, S7, N3, NE12, Kuparuk river, Oksruyurik creek, watershed

description.para:
For Archival Use:
DATE RECEIVED: DATA FILE ENTERED BY: DATA FILE VALIDATION: NAME: DATE:

para.literalLayout: Water samples were collected from prescribed depths in each lake. In the streams, samples were taken at established distances from the phosphorus dripper. Toolik Lake, N-1 and N-2 were sampled weekly as were the streams. The watershed was sampled every 10 days and the other lakes were sampled three times during the summer Sediment traps were sampled weekly by collecting the lower portion of the water in the traps. Samples were brought up to 1 liter with distilled water. Epilithic chlorophyll was sampled from rock from the bottom of riffles in the streams. Using a plastic 35mm slide mount to partition a known area, the algae was scraped from the rock surface with a brass brush. The brushed area of the rock, the brush and slide holder were then rinsed and the slurry collected and brought up to a volume of 53 ml. The samples were returned to the lab where they were filtered through a Gelman A/E glass fiber filter. The filters were then placed in 10 ml of 90% acetone and extracted in the dark for 24 hours. The samples were then mixed, particulates allowed to settle, and then read on a Turner 111 Fluorometer
Reference Citations: R.G. Wetzel & G.E. Likens. 1979. Limnological Methods. Saunders. Philadelphia.
